DOC.HEAD: Possible Lengthy Military Action in Panama Concerns Congress
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are tempering their initial support of President Bush's decision to attack Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's stronghold with concern about the ``renegade'' dictator's elusiveness and a possible long stay in Panama for U.S. troops. ``I can see a scenario whereby the support for this operation could turn difficult for the president,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, told reporters on Wednesday. ``If there is a beginning, middle and end to American military involvement it is far better than having this thing dragging out over weeks and months,'' added Sen. Robert W. Kasten Jr., R-Wis. In the hours after American forces invaded Panama, lawmakers from both parties endorsed Bush's action as the only option left to remove suspected drug trafficker Noriega and establish a democratic government. ``President Bush's actions were justified based on the changing and alarming circumstances of recent weeks in Panama,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a senior Foreign Relations Committee member, called the invasion ``an overwhelming success because democracy has now been inaugurated and installed in Panama.'' But as the day wore on with reports of Americans held captive and Noriega still a fugitive, lawmakers hinted that the U.S. action, dubbed ``Operation Just Cause,'' may prove problematic. ``Noriega continues to elude us and we don't know where he is ... plus the hostage situation, that's a very difficult hostage situation, plus some kind of a continued American presence, loss of life here and there, occasional sniper fire,'' Aspin said. Kasten, ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, stressed the importance of the United States withdrawing its Army rangers and special forces as quickly as possible. International public opinion in Latin America might well turn against the United States if there is ``sustained fighting with U.S. troops in uniform and Panamanian blood being spilled,'' Kasten said. Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., emerging from a classified briefing conducted by Defense and State department officials, said, ``It's fair to say the duration of the operation is of serious concern for a good number of people.'' But Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking minority member on the Senate Armed Services Committee, cautioned against imposing a schedule on troop withdrawal. ``I don't think we should try to impress a time line,'' Warner said after the briefing. Aspin predicted that some U.S. forces will remain in Panama for several months, possibly a year, shoring up the decimated Panamanian Defense Forces, most of whom served as police, custom inspectors or in some public safety capacity. The U.S. presence was likened to the situation in Grenada when American MPs remained for several months after the invasion. In addition to the concern over the presence of U.S. forces, lawmakers said interpretation of the Panamanian invasion as a major achievement was complicated by Noriega, who remains at large. ``The fact that General Noriega is unaccounted for means that the principle issue is unresolved,'' Robb said. ``Now it is our responsibility to track down the renegade General Noriega and bring him to the United States, where he can be tried and punished as the criminal he truly is,'' added Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo. Aspin said he believes Bush will be ``under some political heat if two, three days from now we still have not found Noriega and captured him.'' The Wisconsin Democrat, however, cautioned against judging the success of the operation on whether Noriega is captured. Other lawmakers questioned the invasion's impact on U.S. relations with Central American nations. ``I am gravely concerned ... that this unilateral military intervention may do long-term damage to our foreign policy, to our ability to work with other nations in Latin America, and to our goal of achieving lasting democracy in the region,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.
